title: George Rogers Clark National Historical Park: Park Home
body: "Great things have been effected by a few men well conducted."  The British flag would not be raised above Fort Sackville Feb. 25, 1779. At 10 a.m., the garrison surrendered to American Colonel George Rogers Clark. His American army, aided by French residents of the Illinois country, had marched through freezing floodwaters to gain this victory. The fortâ€™s capture assured United States claims to the frontier, an area nearly as large as the original 13 states.                2016 American Solar Challenge   Join us on July 31 for the American Solar Challenge, hosted by the National Park Service and the Innovators Educational Foundation.        Summer Junior Ranger Series   Join park staff and volunteers for a summer full of fun and exciting hands-on activities!        The Story   To capture British forces, George Rogers Clark and his men marched across flooded prairies to reach Fort Sackville
